fact: The ISS travels at about 28,000 kilometers per hour (17,500 miles per hour), orbiting Earth roughly every 90 minutes.
Astronauts aboard the ISS see about 16 sunrises and sunsets each day.
The ISS is roughly the size of a football field — about 73 meters by 109 meters (including solar arrays).
The first module of the ISS was launched in 1998 and the station has been continuously occupied since November 2000.
Water aboard the ISS is recycled — urine, sweat, and cabin condensate are reclaimed to produce drinking water.
The station’s solar arrays generate more than 100 kilowatts of electricity — enough power for about 40 average homes.
Microgravity experiments on the ISS help scientists study things that are difficult or impossible on Earth, from protein crystals to combustion.
The ISS orbits at an altitude between about 400 and 420 kilometers (approximately 250 miles) above Earth.
The station is a collaboration between five space agencies: NASA (USA), Roscosmos (Russia), JAXA (Japan), ESA (Europe), and CSA (Canada).
The cupola is a seven-windowed observatory module on the ISS used for viewing Earth and robotic operations.
Food on the ISS is specially packaged; some foods are rehydrated, some are thermostabilized, and many are familiar to crews.
The ISS supports educational outreach — students around the world can talk to astronauts and run experiments.
